fields.title: The ^Cavalry Game
fields.production_note: H P Gibson & Sons Ltd, London, EC3. Copyright, reserved.
fields.historical_context_note:
Rewards: n/a
Forfeits: n/a
No. of Players: any
Equipment required: 41 cards of which 10 are the BRIGADE cards printed in red to show the number of the Brigade and the regiments which made each up 
the rest are SOLDIER cards, each printed in colours to show an illustration of a cavalry soldiers.
Brigades from the 1st to the 10th each have 3 cards except the 3rd Brigade which has 4 cards.


Rules:
THE CAVALRY GAME, COPYRIGHT:  H P GIBSON & SONS LTD, LONDON, E C 3

This game was invented in the hope that it might teach some of our boys and girls the names and numbers of the British Cavalry Regiments.
The pack consists of 41 cards, 10 being Brigade Cards and the rest being the Soldier cards.  The Brigades have been formed in order of the numbers, not by the names.  It will be seen that in the 5th Brigade, for instance, there are the 4th Hussars, 3rd Lancers and 6th Dragons.  By this means it is hoped that the players will remember which number belongs to each regiment.  In the same the 3rd Brigade is composed of four Regiments instead of three.  This is done simply to keep the numbers in order.  It is taken for granted that the players know that there are seven D G Regiments.

RULES
1.  The game to be played by from three to six players.
2.  The whole of the pack should be well shuffled and dealt round, after which each player should arrange his hand in Brigades, where possible.
3.  The object of the player holding one or more cards belonging to a Brigade is to obtain the rest of the soldiers belonging to his Brigade.  The player who first obtains four Brigades makes a Cavalry Division and wins the game.
4.  The player on the left of the dealer beings by asking anyone of the other players for a card which will help him to form a Brigade.
5.  When a card is demanded of a player and he he holds it, he must forfeit it and the successful caller may proceed to demand from that player or any other player another card until he fails when the turn passes to the last player he has asked.
6.  If a player asks for a card which he already holds, the turn passes to the player from whom he asked it. 
7.  A player must not ask for a soldier unless he has either the Brigade card or a soldier forming the Brigade.
8.  If a player has no Brigade cards he may ask for one as long as he has one of the cards forming the Brigade.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------PICTORIAL CARD CARDS advertised on the rules card of the game
ALICE IN WONDERLAND (48 cards); ANIMAL GRAB (52); CHEERY FAMILIES (52)
GIPSY (33); GOLLIWOGG (48); NOAH'S ARK (52); SNAP (52); SPIN AND OLD MAID (40); BREAD AND HONEY (53); CAVALRY (41); JUNGLE JINKS (48); PETER PAN(52)

GENERAL HAPPY FAMILIES RULES

Three or more can play and special cards are normally used, each showing four members of a family, mother, father, son and daughter,  However, variations have been developed to use groups of 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7 to a set.  Also subject variations occur and some are educational, for example The Counties of England.

The object of the game is for each player to collect as many complete `families' as possible.  
One of the players deals out all the cards.  If more than one round is played, the players take it in turn to deal.  It does not matter if some players have one card more than others.
Each player looks at his cards and sorts them into families.
It is important that players keep their cards hidden from each other.  With young children it is a good idea if they can lay their cards out of view of the other players.
When all the players are ready, the person to the dealer's left asks any player, by name, for a particular card (eg Master Baker).  He must already possess at least one of member of the same family, ie Mrs. Baker.  If the person asked has the card, he must give it to the first player, who may again ask anybody for a card of any family as long as he already has one card belonging to that family.  
He continues to do this until he fails to obtain a card.  If the person asked does not have the card requested, it is his turn to ask for cards.
When a player collects all the cards of the same family, he puts them into a pile face down in front of him.
Play continues until all the families have been completed
The winner is the person who collects the most families.
